conclusion: Draw the forces on the suitcase.

On the suitcase act: weight mg = 15 kg × 10 m/s² = 150 N (down), normal reaction of the ground N (up), pulling force F = 90 N, making an angle θ above the horizontal, horizontal component Fₓ = F cos θ (forward), vertical component Fᵧ = F sin θ (up), kinetic friction f = μ N (backward).

premise: Because the suitcase moves at constant velocity on a horizontal floor, the net horizontal and vertical forces are zero.
conclusion: Write the equilibrium equations: Vertical: N + F sin θ = mg → N = mg – F sin θ (1), Horizontal: F cos θ = μ N (2).

premise: Insert (1) in (2): F cos θ = μ (mg – F sin θ)
conclusion: F cos θ + μ F sin θ = μ mg, F (cos θ + μ sin θ) = μ mg, F(θ) = μ mg / (cos θ + μ sin θ) (3).

premise: For a fixed μ the numerator of (3) is constant, so the pull is minimal when the denominator D(θ) = cos θ + μ sin θ is maximal.
conclusion: The maximum of a cos θ + b sin θ is √(a² + b²). Thus D_max = √(1 + μ²) and it is reached when dD/dθ = –sin θ + μ cos θ = 0 → tan θ = μ (4).

premise: At that optimal angle the minimum pull is F_min = μ mg / √(1 + μ²) = 90 N (5). Insert m g = 150 N.

conclusion: tan 37° ≈ 0.75 (the data sin 37° = 0.6 are supplied in the problem), so θ ≈ 37°. Indeed, with θ = 37° we have sin θ ≈ 0.6, cos θ ≈ 0.8, tan θ ≈ 0.75.

premise: Coefficient of (rolling) friction μ = 0.75, Angle of the pull above the horizontal θ ≈ 37°.
